author: -JuDo loVer-

text:
import random
import curses


s = curses.initscr()
curses.curs_set(0)
sh, sw = s.getmaxyx()
w = curses.newwin(sh, sw, 0, 0)
w.keypad(1)
w.timeout(100)
score = 0


snk_x = sw/4
snk_y = sh/2
snake = [
    [snk_y, snk_x],
    [snk_y, snk_x-1],
    [snk_y, snk_x-2]
]


food = [sh/2, sw/2]
w.addch(int(food[0]), int(food[1]), curses.ACS_PI)


key = curses.KEY_RIGHT


while True:
    next_key = w.getch()
    key = key if next_key == -1 else next_key


    if snake[0][0] in [0, sh] or snake[0][1]  in [0, sw] or snake[0] in snake[1:]:
        curses.endwin()
        print(score)
        quit()


    new_head = [snake[0][0], snake[0][1]]


    if key == curses.KEY_DOWN:
        new_head[0] += 1
    if key == curses.KEY_UP:
        new_head[0] -= 1
    if key == curses.KEY_LEFT:
        new_head[1] -= 1
    if key == curses.KEY_RIGHT:
        new_head[1] += 1


    snake.insert(0, new_head)
    if snake[0] == food:
        score += 1
        food = None
        while food is None:
            nf = [
                random.randint(1, sh-1),
                random.randint(1, sw-1)
            ]
            food = nf if nf not in snake else None
        w.addch(int(food[0]), int(food[1]), curses.ACS_PI)
    else:
        tail = snake.pop()
        w.addch(int(tail[0]), int(tail[1]), ' ')


    w.addch(int(snake[0][0]), int(snake[0][1]), curses.ACS_CKBOARD)


this should work, and I added a feature to keep track of score﻿

author: Ridham Govind

text:
In case any of y'all wondering how to get this to run on both python 2 and 3, you need to make a few changes to the original code:

A lot of people suggested converting the first two arguments in the addch() method to integers, but this has some complications.  Instead of this, whenever you divide "sh" or "sw", use the "//" operator instead (this floors the decimal number). 

In the while loop, wrap all the code in a try block, and created an except block to print "Game over" (this usually happens when the snake hits the edge of the terminal) and add the quit() method at the end of the except block.﻿

author: Mohan J

text:
I added a small feature:
If you go up, and press down in this game, you die.
The following code just ignores you if you tell the snake to do a 180:


key = key if\
        next_key == -1 or\
        (key == curses.KEY_UP and next_key == curses.KEY_DOWN) or\
        (key == curses.KEY_DOWN and next_key == curses.KEY_UP) or\
        (key == curses.KEY_LEFT and next_key == curses.KEY_RIGHT) or\
        (key == curses.KEY_RIGHT and next_key == curses.KEY_LEFT)\
else next_key

maybe there's a less "hardcodey" way to do this, but it works.


the "\" makes it so that you can have a statement across multiple lines.﻿

author: Black Jesus

text:
whats wrong with my code??????????

import  random
import curses

s=curses.initscr()
curses.curs_set(0)
sh,sw=s.getmaxyx()
w=curses.newwin(sh,sw,0,0)
w.keypad(1)
w.timeout(100)
snk_x=sw/4
snk_y=sh/2
snake=[
    [snk_y,snk_x]
    [snk_y,snk_x-1]
    [snk_y,snk_x-2]
]
food=[sh/2,sw/2]
w.addch(food[0],food[1],curses.ACS_PI)
key=curses.KEY_RIGHT
while True:
    next_key=w.getch()
    key=key if next_key==-1 else next_key
    if snake[0][0] in [0,sh] or snake[0][1] in [0,sw] or snake[0] in snake[1:]:
        curses.endwin()
        quit()

    new_head =[snake[0][0], snake[0][1]]
    if key==curses.KEY_DOWN:
        new_head[0]+1
    if key==curses.KEY_UP:
        new_head[0]-1
    if key==curses.KEY_LEFT:
        new_head[1]-1
    if key==curses.KEY_RIGHT:
        new_head[1]+1

    snake.insert(0,new_head)
    if snake[0]==food:
        food=None
        while food is None:
            nf=[
                random.randint(1,sh-1),
                random.randint(1, sw - 1)
            ]
            food=nf if nf not in snake else None
        w.addch(food[0],food[1],curses.ACS_PI)
    else:
        tail=snake.pop()
        w.addch(tail[0],tail[1]," ")
    w.addch(snake[0][0],snake[0][1],curses.ACS_CKBOARD)﻿

author: Murilo Escher

text:
Great video, I enjoyed watching it and subbed as a result. As someone who is fairly new to python but has years of experience in other languages I'd love to see the real process of putting together this game, from conception to coding to the finished game. Mistakes and problems included.

I think only those with no experience or very little experience know that it's next to impossible (or very very difficult at least) to code a game on the fly like this and only have a few small mistakes in under 5 minutes.

Saying that, your style made this video highly enjoyable and I'm looking forward to to watching your other content. 

I'm not sure who you are aiming the video at however,  who your target audience actually are? people who are learning python who have little to no previous experience or someone with a more advanced level?  To offer some constructive criticism, and honestly I am not meaning any disrespect here.. But I think if you fine tuned your videos to either cater to true beginners in some videos and then in others maybe fine tune them for more advanced developers you might find your channel blows up and truly takes off. You could easily become a 100k subscriber channel or more, your content is really good.﻿

author: Shane Lee

text:
@Shane Lee Everybody uses them, because it makes sense.
If there are missing semicolons, javascript parser will try to autofill them where it thinks they are necessary. Which may break your code for no obvious reasons if it autofills badly. Not to mention, if you're programming either in WebGL or using Javascript code in C++ or C# through some bridges, you have to use semicolons with no exceptions.﻿

text: Dimitrios Chatzidimitriou I've not seen his channel but I believe I've read a book of his called  The Nature of Code which is a quick dive into visual programming with Processing and touches on a heap of very interesting concepts starting off REALLY simple with things like simple animations, vectors, forces, creating basic physics engines, box2d. Then moving on to cellular automata, genetic programming, neural networks, and ties everything in with the common thread of mimicking nature in code, and for anyone who hasn't used Processing (it's basically a framework built on Java that makes it FAR easier to quickly "sketch" visual programs, rather than using Java Swing or AWT.) I HIGHLY recommend it. And I HIGHLY recommend the book "The Nature of Code" which is free to read online. Donations are accepted and a hard copy can be purchased.﻿

author: Miles Williams

text:
Alex Garbarino I wouldn't recommend Unity for someone who isn't a fluent programmer. Sure, you can patch together things. Use other peoples assets and code, but you won't understand what you're doing. Learn basic C# or JS first before diving into Unity. It's an ENORMOUS tool that'll overwhelm you.
If you have a basic understanding of C# or JS then when you read other peoples code in Unity you will be able to learn. And there is no better way to learn how to code than to read the code written by people who know what they are doing, excluding writing your own code, that is the number one way to get good, pick a problem, write a solution, get stuck, figure it out, find your code is broken, fix it, find it runs slow, refactor it, find it doesn't work in certain cases, create unit tests for it. Best way to learn to code is to CODE!﻿

author: Truman P

text:
@Engineer Man Reasonable assumption, except that the title of this video is "*Create* a Snake game with Python in under 5 minutes," so you're leading people on. I don't know Python, but I've programmed in many different languages over the years. With each new language, there was always some cool feature added that made me think "Man, that one line can do what takes 10-100 lines of code in other language 'X'." (I'm exaggerating, but you get the point.) So, how do I know that there isn't some awesome construct, data type, logic, etc. that would condense this program to the point that it could be conceptualized and coded in 5 minutes? I don't know that, so I take the title at its word, until proven otherwise. Even your one-line description reinforces the idea that it was created from scratch.

But, then I see your eyes darting back and forth to your second screen and voilà! Illusion destroyed.

OTH, I loved your video about showing a scammer who's boss. That looked like you actually wrote it off the top of your head. Did you? In any case, I dove into python using this. I installed the 'requests' library/module/thingy and followed your code, made a few changes - shuffled the list of names, used 5-10 different domains instead of pinning everything on yahoo.com, etc. - and off it goes! It's great! I love it. I run it a few times a day when I flip into Terminal to do something else and I see that it's still there.

Anyway, I like your videos, but would appreciate a bit more honesty with the title of this one. Makes me wary about the other ones.﻿

author: Omer Duchovne

text:
No, I hear ya. What you're missing is this video is designed more for entertainment than education. All of my other videos are geared towards education. You'll notice all those, though somewhat fast paced, focus on a very specific topic that could probably be described briefly in 20 seconds.

These videos are time consuming to produce, so I have to be cognizant about who I'm looking to target as to maximize the value to effort ratio. This is also a new channel, so I'm still carving out a specific niche. I have received a lot of request for beginner type videos, so I would certainly expect to see more of those in the future.

You'll also notice this video got about 250x more views than my average view count. I'd be a fool not to make more.﻿

author: Adoo

text:
import random
import curses

s = curses.initscr()
curses.curs_set(0)
sh, sw = s.getmaxyx()
w = curses.newwin(sh, sw, 0, 0)
w.keypad(1)
w.tomeout(100)

snk_x = sw/4
snk_y = sh/2
snake = [
    [snk_y, snk_x],
    [snk_y, snk_x-1],
    [snk_y, snk_x-2]
]

food = [sh/2, sw/2]
w.addich(food[0], food[1], curses.ACS_PI)

key = curses.KEY_RIGHT

while True:
    next_key = w.getch()
    key = key if next_key == -1 else next_key

    if snake[0][0] in [0, sh] or snake[0][1] in [0, sw] or snake[0] in snake[1:]:
        curses.endwin()
        quit()

    new_head = [snake[0][0], snake[0][1]]

    if key == curses.KEY_DOWN:
        new_head[0] += 1
    if key == curses.KEY_UP:
        new_head[0] -= 1
    if key == curses.KEY_LEFT:
        new_head[1] -= 1
    if key == curses.KEY_RIGHT:
        new_head[1] += 1

        snake.insert(0, new_head0)
    if snake[0] == food:
        food = None
        while food is None:
            nf = [
                random.randint(1, sh-1),
                random.randint(1, sw-1)
            ]
            food = nf if nf not in snake else None
        w.addch(food[0], food[1], curses.ACS_PI)
    else:
        tail = snake.pop()
        w.addch(tail[0], tail[1], ' ')

    w.addch(snake[0][0], snake[0][1], curses.ACS_CKBOARD)﻿

text:
Python 3 code that works (download whl file , for more info look below comments  ): 

import random
import curses

s = curses.initscr()
curses.curs_set(0)
sh, sw = s.getmaxyx()
w = curses.newwin(sh, sw, 0, 0)
w.keypad(1)
w.timeout(100)

snk_x = sw/4
snk_y = sh/2
snake = [
    [snk_y, snk_x],
    [snk_y, snk_x-1],
    [snk_y, snk_x-2]
]

food = [int(sh/2), int(sw/2)] # Added here
w.addch(food[0], food[1], curses.ACS_PI)

key = curses.KEY_RIGHT

while True:
    next_key = w.getch()
    key = key if next_key == -1 else next_key

    if snake[0][0] in [0, sh] or snake[0][1]  in [0, sw] or snake[0] in snake[1:]:
        curses.endwin()
        quit()

    new_head = [snake[0][0], snake[0][1]]

    if key == curses.KEY_DOWN:
        new_head[0] += 1
    if key == curses.KEY_UP:
        new_head[0] -= 1
    if key == curses.KEY_LEFT:
        new_head[1] -= 1
    if key == curses.KEY_RIGHT:
        new_head[1] += 1

    snake.insert(0, new_head)

    if snake[0] == food:
        food = None
        while food is None:
            nf = [
                random.randint(1, sh-1),
                random.randint(1, sw-1)
            ]
            food = nf if nf not in snake else None
        w.addch(food[0], food[1], curses.ACS_PI)
    else:
        tail = snake.pop()
        w.addch(int(tail[0]), int(tail[1]), ' ') # addeded here

    w.addch(int(snake[0][0]), int(snake[0][1]), curses.ACS_CKBOARD)﻿

author: Engineer Man

text: I am an amateur, barely playing with python. So why don't people migrate to python 3 since it has been updated to 3.6 already? stability?efficiency?compatibility of packages and modules? just of curiosity as, for personal interest in programming, I won't need them so far...﻿
author: 李爽

text:
The short answer is: If you are starting a new application, use python3.

The long answer is:
As you just discovered, it isn't as easy as just running a program with python3 rather than python2. This is a main reason why people don't use it. Here is a small list of reasons why you'd still use python2:
- You have a large complex python2 app and refactoring it to python3 is too expensive
- You have an app part of critical infrastructure and refactoring is a safety risk
- You depend heavily on, or would like to use a python2 library which is either not available or poorly ported to python3
- You must operate in an environment where python3 is not available by default (older CentOS distros come to mind)

I have no decent excuse for not writing the snake game in 3. For the sake of expediency, I wanted to use what I knew well.﻿

author: Dakota Felspar

text: The trick is you will never be this good at coding. Sure maybe for simple stuff. But you'll never be able to think AHA! I know exactly what to do when faced with all these problems! And then proceed to start typing constantly. It doesn't work like that. You have to plan out your idea, plan your code structure, and research any gaps in your knowledge or issues you may have. Then code and debug. Generally what a decent coder will spend their time on a project doing is 20% planning, 30% research, 30% coding and 20% debugging. And there's also Pareto principle, which in other words is the 80/20 rule. 80% of the work will take 20% of the time, where as the last 20% will take 80% of the time.﻿

author: MrGeekGamer

text:
This video has had a mixed reception. A bunch of people on Reddit accused me of just copying source code from a second monitor. While I obviously designed the program ahead of time (as it would have been impractical not to), all I was looking at was program notes to remind me about important chunks of the code. This video took me over 30 takes and I spent probably 7x the amount of time that I normally do per video. If I really wanted to conceal the fact that I was copying source code over, I would have just turned off my camera for this video. Could have saved a lot of time, too.


I found a niche in C and Linux. I'll probably just stick to that.﻿
